repnme.cdata!:
Czech Republic - Ozone depleting substances
            phase-out : global environment facility (GEF)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Czechoslovakia country program (CP)
            for the phase-out of ozone depleting Substances (ODS) (3935
            tons, and the Czech Republic accounted for 60 percent of
            it), that builds the basis of the global environment
            facility (GEF) project for the phase-out of ODS in the Czech
            Republic, was completed in August 1992. All
            chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) production was phased out, a
            national network for refrigerant recovery reclamation and
            recycling (3R) was introduced, and technology changes were
            implemented to use ODS substitutes in manufacturing goods,
            mainly refrigeration and commercial, industrial cooling
            applications. GEF support provided an incentive for the
            early adoption of ODS phase-out activities and captured
            additional environmental and economic benefits which
            otherwise will have been lost or delayed. The GEF project
            consisted of five subprojects, including four investment
            subprojects and one institutional strengthening subproject.
            One sub-project, which involved funding a feasibility study
            to convert CFC production facilities was abandoned when it
            was assessed that there will be no profitable market for the
            new products. The Czech Ministry of Environment considers
            improving the effectiveness of the 3R scheme by a national
            program and hopes to address the shortcoming in particular
            by special training activities to be conducted by the
            association of refrigeration servicemen (green card).

repnme.cdata!:
Czech Republic - Technical Support and
            Investment Project for the Phaseout of Ozone Depleting Substances

abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project's objectives
            were fully achieved. ODS (ozone depleting substances)
            production and use of primary CFCs (chlorofluorocarbons)
            were phased out through the implementation of the
            sub-projects and legislative enactment. In addition to
            meeting some of the incremental costs of phase-out, this
            GEF-funded (Global Environment Facility) project enabled
            appropriate Western technologies to be identified and
            introduced into the country. Despite these positive
            outcomes, the performance of the 3R component (recovery,
            reclamation, and recycling) was unsatisfactory. Lessons
            learned from this project include: 1) Establishing and
            improving the proper legal and regulatory framework, and the
            institutional system were essential. 2) All sub-projects
            experienced a "learning curve" as ideas and
            technologies imported from the West needed adapting before
            they could be transferred. 3) Earlier legislation
            encouraging the recovery of refrigerants by imposing a heavy
            excise duty on CFCs backfired to some degree. The report
            also evaluates the cooperation of beneficiaries; bank
            performance in preparing, appraising, and implementing the
            project; the need for the project implementation unit and
            its manager to be given authority to take a more proactive
            role; the effect of commercial incentives for participants;
            and the now principal challenge of making the entire 3R
            scheme reach its anticipated capacity.

repnme.cdata!:
Czech Republic - Technical Support and
            Investment Project for the Phaseout of Ozone Depleting Substances

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal objective of this
            Technical Support and Investment Project for the Phaseout of
            Ozone Depleting Substances is to assist the Czech Republic
            in the phaseout of Ozone Depleting Substances (ODS)
            production and consumption in a cost effective manner by the
            year 1996. Specifically this project will assist the Czech
            Republic to: a) initiate the phase out of the production of
            chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs); b) phase in the operation of a
            national network for refrigerant recovery/reclamation/
            recycling; and c) support applied engineering efforts to use
            ODS substitutes in manufactured goods, thereby reducing the
            immediate and future needs for regulated subjects. There are
            5 sub-projects including: a) engineering assistance for ODS
            production phaseout; b) design and operation of CFC
            refrigerant reclamation facilities and establishment of
            refrigerant recovery capacity in the national network of
            servicing companies; c) introduction of non-ODS refrigerant
            in the commercial, industrial and refrigerated transport
            sectors; d) introduction of non-ODS insulation technologies
            in cold room panel manufacturing; and e) setup of a project
            management unit (PMU).
